parts:
Hi DR. Today we are going to be collecting evidence for a research paper. 

# Ground rules

ABOVE ALL ELSE, if you are unsure about something, or do not have evidence from a web page supporting a claim, do not make a claim. If there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

This is research. SPEND EXTRA TIME above and beyond normal, to collect data carefully and methodically. We don't care about how long it takes, only that your research is accurate and epistemologically grounded. Care and attention to detail second only to the prior rule.

# Definitions

## Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

It is our belief that the tools we have given you meet this criteria, however, if there is an absence of evidence supporting our belief, it is REQUIRED that you inform us of any problems. IF YOU ARE UNSURE, INDICATE IT rather than giving an answer.

# Task

I will be giving you the name or acronym of an archaeology and historical studies-related software tool which dates somewhere from 1995 onwards. 

You must build a well-formed quoted CSV inside a fenced code block with the following columns:
csv
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"

* Tool is our key column. It is essential to be consistent in tool name, following the input we give you. If there is an issue indicate it in notes.
* Year, year from the web page, article, or source you found, n.d. is a valid entry for "no date"
* Source: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
* URL, url of the resource. 
* AI notes: any notes, concerns, or uncertainties you have with the data provenance or quality. Do not use HTML citations.

This is a comprehensive and systematic search. For each year, 1995 onwards, we one mention (one line) per source found. Obviously, many of these tools were created after 1995, so we'll want to expand our search by +- 1 year from any date we find. When you find a source, systematically explore adjacent years in your searches.

DO NOT extrapolate dates from sources. ONLY include dates where a source has been published in that year. We will perform all necessary inference, if you include a line for EACH valid source you find. For undated items, indicate "n.d."

This research requires that you be thoughtful, systematic, and take your time. You will likely need to visit EVERY SINGLE PAGE of search results for a given tool. 

To repeat back.

I'm going to give you a list of tools, one by one.
You will search for them.
For every source you find,  we want to record tool, year/n.d., source (citation or title), and url

You MUST build a CSV with the output in your direct response to the deep research process.

Allowed sources: 
* Do try to find it's source code in published version control repos (add a row if they have public code, as the commits will have dates)
* do try to find scholarly literature (each to one row)
* do include blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
* do include any other mentions of the tool (each to one row)

When you respond with data:
RESULTS: Build a markdown **fenced code block** CSV of evidence you have found with  ANY mention of that tool in ANY year/n.d. should be on the CSV, regardless of source. Include one line for EACH source you find. Do not include any inline citations automatically generated by the deep research process (i.e., AI-generated or system-injected references i.e. 【deep research】 or ​:contentReference[oaicite). 

Do you understand?
Yes, I understand the research methodology and requirements. Please provide the first software tool name, and I will begin the systematic and thorough search following the outlined guidelines.

Understood. I will conduct a systematic and thorough search for any mentions of the software tool **HumanOS** related to archaeology or historical sciences from 1995 onwards. This includes scholarly literature, version control repositories, blog posts, about pages, and any other sources that confirm its existence and functionality. I will document each source found in a quoted CSV format with relevant details. 

I'll get back to you with the compiled data as soon as the research is complete.

content.text:
{"task_violates_safety_guidelines":false,"user_def_doesnt_want_research":false,"response":"Understood. I will conduct a systematic and thorough search for any mentions of the software tool **HumanOS** related to archaeology or historical sciences from 1995 onwards. This includes scholarly literature, version control repositories, blog posts, about pages, and any other sources that confirm its existence and functionality. I will document each source found in a quoted CSV format with relevant details. 

I'll get back to you with the compiled data as soon as the research is complete.","title":"Comprehensive Evidence Collection for HumanOS","prompt":"Conduct a detailed and systematic search for the software tool **HumanOS** in relation to archaeology or historical sciences, covering sources from 1995 onwards. For every mention found, record the following details in a quoted CSV format:

- **Tool**: "HumanOS" (Maintain consistent naming)
- **Year**: The publication or mention year from the source. If undated, use "n.d."
- **Source**: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
- **URL**: Direct link to the source
- **AI Notes**: Any concerns, doubts, or context regarding data provenance and quality.

Follow a rigorous methodology:
1. **Examine Every Search Result Page** for the tool systematically.
2. **Include All Valid Sources**: Scholarly literature, version control repositories, blog posts, about pages, and other credible mentions.
3. **Do Not Infer Dates**: Only include explicitly stated years.
4. **Expand Searches for Adjacent Years** to ensure comprehensive coverage.

Provide results in a **fenced code block CSV format** as per the specified structure. Accuracy and attention to detail are paramount."}

metadata.async_task_prompt:
Conduct a detailed and systematic search for the software tool **HumanOS** in relation to archaeology or historical sciences, covering sources from 1995 onwards. For every mention found, record the following details in a quoted CSV format:

- **Tool**: "HumanOS" (Maintain consistent naming)
- **Year**: The publication or mention year from the source. If undated, use "n.d."
- **Source**: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
- **URL**: Direct link to the source
- **AI Notes**: Any concerns, doubts, or context regarding data provenance and quality.

Follow a rigorous methodology:
1. **Examine Every Search Result Page** for the tool systematically.
2. **Include All Valid Sources**: Scholarly literature, version control repositories, blog posts, about pages, and other credible mentions.
3. **Do Not Infer Dates**: Only include explicitly stated years.
4. **Expand Searches for Adjacent Years** to ensure comprehensive coverage.

Provide results in a **fenced code block CSV format** as per the specified structure. Accuracy and attention to detail are paramount.

parts:
```csv
"Tool","Year","Source","URL","AI Notes"
"HumanOS","2016","Archéorient – Société d’Anthropologie de Paris 2016 Program","https://www.archeorient.mom.fr/sites/archeorient.mom.fr/files/docs/Activites/Livret_SAP.pdf","Conference poster abstract (listing in program) – limited information, but confirms early mention of HumanOS."
"HumanOS","2016","ResearchGate – “HumanOs Project: a Nomadic Osteological Inventory” (44th CAA Conference)","https://www.researchgate.net/publication/311716464_HumanOs_Project_a_Nomadic_Osteological_Inventory","Conference presentation (CAA 2016) – abstract available via ResearchGate; not a peer-reviewed article, but an official project introduction."
"HumanOS","2018","Archéo-Nil – “La fouille des sépultures: du terrain à l’enregistrement…digitale des données”","https://www.persee.fr/doc/arnil_1161-0492_2018_num_28_1_1299","Peer-reviewed journal article (in French) describing systematic burial recording; publication provides context for HumanOS’s development (content accessed via reference, full text not readily online)."
"HumanOS","2020","Virtual Archaeology Review – HumanOS: an open source nomadic software database for physical anthropology and archaeology","https://riunet.upv.es/handle/10251/148110","Peer-reviewed article introducing HumanOS in detail – primary source by the developers (Rozenn Colleter et al.); high-quality, citable description of the tool."
"HumanOS","2020","HumanOS Project Site (CNRS) – “HumanOS – l’inventaire ostéologique nomade”","http://www.humanos.cnrs.fr","Official project website (in French) providing download and tutorial; cites the 2020 publication. Reliable but essentially reproduces information from the 2020 paper (no additional date beyond 2020)."
"HumanOS","2020","Iris Publishers (OAJAA) – “VirtualAnthroPy: Towards an Open-Source Tool for the Visualization of 2D Anthropology Images Positioned in 3D”","https://irispublishers.com/oajaa/fulltext/virtualanthropy-towards-an-open-source-tool-for-the-visualization-of-2d-anthropology.ID.000546.php","Open-access article (Sept 2020) referencing HumanOS as a data source for a visualization tool. Provides usage context; publisher is less established, so content credibility should be considered accordingly."
"HumanOS","2022","PLOS ONE – “Talking Dead: New burials from Tron Bon Lei (Alor Island, Indonesia)…”","https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0267635","Peer-reviewed research article using HumanOS for data recording (mortuary archaeology context). High-quality source; demonstrates adoption of HumanOS in scholarly work."
"HumanOS","2023","Morphologie (PubMed) – “Conformational variations of the medial epicondyle of the humerus…”","https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36775677","Peer-reviewed anatomy/anthropology journal article (2023) – methods note the use of HumanOS for skeletal data. Credible source; content behind paywall, but reference to HumanOS is documented."
"HumanOS","2023","Anthropological Review – “Spina Bifida Sacralis Occulta…Pozzanghera Necropolis, Leontinoi… (6th–4th Century BC)”","https://czasopisma.uni.lodz.pl/ar/article/view/18264","Peer-reviewed anthropology journal article (2023) mentioning HumanOS for digital skeletal inventory. Reliable academic source; the mention is noted in text (as per preview), though full text access is limited."
"HumanOS","n.d.","cagt.cnrs.fr – Software and Data (CAGT)","https://cagt.cnrs.fr/softwares-and-data/","Institutional website listing (Centre for Anthropobiology & Genomics of Toulouse) – includes HumanOS among research software. No publication date provided on page (likely updated ~2020); useful for provenance but offers no additional details on the tool."
```
